title: Just filed for chapter 13 two months ago. Now I just got laid off? What are my options
question: I received a severance package when I was laid off. I filed chapter seven 3 years ago. Any suggestions please.
answers: Discuss with your BK attorney. If you do not have one or need a second opinion, arrange a consultation asap. As your finances change, the viability of your bankruptcy plan may change. If you are trying to save a home from foreclosure, alternatives to Chapter 13 may be available. Get help now.

As indicated by other counsel, your options are somewhat limited and depend upon the reason you filed. If facing a foreclosure, you may need to string the case along until you get a new job. If you were fighting a wage garnishment, the job termination would take care of that for a while.
Talk to your attorney. If you don't have one, contact one and discuss your options.

What was your Chapter 13 goal? If to prevent wage garnishment, that may no longer be an issue if you have no wages to garnish. Unemployment benefits are generally exempt in every state. Hope this perspective helps!

In the abstract your options are to (1) dismiss the case now (with an eye toward refilling when you get a job), or (2) you can probably string the case along 2 months or so (if you know what you are doing...I hope you have an attorney). However, you will have to obtain a reliable source of income that will allow you feasibly continue the chapter 13. Since you are likely pre-confirmation (i.e your plan hasn't been confirmed), you don't have a much time.

This happens more often than you think. Heck, it just happened to one of my clients.

As for what to do specific for your situation, that depends on why you filed the chapter 13. If you filed to save your home from foreclosure, that is a much bigger mess to sort out.

Given that you filed a ch7 3 years ago, you are ineligible to convert to a ch7. You were not eligible for a ch13 discharge when you filed this 13. Unfortunately, other than finding a new job, you may not have a lot of options. If you have an attorney discuss whether a motion for a moratorium is possible. That could buy you a month or two.

Please consult with your attorney. Depending on the circumstance, you may want to apply for a moratorium until you get a new job. Or you may want to convert to a Chapter 7. But it depends upon your circumstances.

The answer to this question depends on the reason you filed chapter 13 in the first place. Income above the means test disqualifying you from chapter 7? To stop a foreclosure? To protect property that would be lost in chapter 7? Too much disposable income for chapter 7? If due to decreased income, you would now qualify for chapter 7, then conversion is possible. You need to speak to your attorney. if you don't have one, you need to discuss this with an attorney who would be familiar with your situation.

Good luck.
